title.narrative: FAO & UNICEF support to families affected by drought 2014 in Guatemala.
FAO & UNICEF stöd till familjer som drabbats av torkan i Guatemala år 2014.

description.narrative: Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Guatemala has experienced a prolonged drought during 2014 affecting the north east of the country. The drought has particularly affected smallholder farmers with subsistence and infra subsistence production in the area known as the dry corridor. The Guatemalan government declared a state of emergency in the affected departments and submitted an appeal for humanitarian aid. The government, through its Council of Nutrition and Food Security, SESAN (for its acronym in Spanish), has recognized the damages caused by the extended drought. This led to the government declaring State of Public Calamity in the departments affected and made an appeal for humanitarian assistance. The government also launched a plan to attend the population affected that includes three strategies: 1) humanitarian assistance, 2) livelihoods recovery and 3) resilience and adaptation to climate change. The United Nations system in Guatemala presented a response plan in reaction to the government's request for support. This project is based on the proposed roles for FAO and UNICEF in the medium and long term of the plan. The project is therefore in line with the Guatemalan government plan for the assistance in the medium and long term: 2) recovery of livelihoods and 3) the resilience and adaptation to climate change. The project application is for a period of two years and a budget of 20 MSEK. The contribution aims to recover the livelihoods of the families affected by prolonged drought of 2014, as well as, to create resilience through management and conservation of soil and water in Chiquimula and Jalapa.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Guatemala har upplevt en förlängd period av torka under 2014, vilket har påverkan främst i de nordöstra delarna av landet och det område som kallas "den torra korridoren". Torkan har särskilt påverkat personer i fattigdom och extremfattigdom som är beroende av jordbruk för deras uppehälle. Guatemalas regering förklarade katastroftillstånd i de drabbade departementen och framförde en vädjan om humanitärt bistånd. Regeringen lanserade också en plan bistå befolkningen som drabbats. Planen omfattar tre strategier: 1) humanitärt bistånd, 2) återhämtning av försörjningsmöjligheter och 3) motståndskraft och anpassning till klimatförändringar. FN systemet i Guatemala presenterade en omgripande plan som svar på regeringens förfrågan om stöd. Detta projekt är baserat på FAO och UNICEFs föreslagna roller på medel- och långsikt i den planen. Projektet är därmed i linje med Guatemalas regeringsplan för bistånd på medellång och lång sikt: 2) återhämtning av försörjningsmöjligheter och 3) motståndskraft och anpassning till klimatförändringar. Projektansökan är för en period på två år och budgeten är på 20 MSEK. Initiativet syftar till att återställa försörjningsmöjligheter för de familjer som drabbats av den långvariga torkan under 2014, samt skapa motståndskraft hos dem genom metoder för handhålland och bevarande av jord och vatten i kommuner i regionerna Chiquimula och Jalapa.

description.narrative: During 2019, 2,021 families from which 64% are women household harvest 14.1 million liters of rainwater, this allowed them to produce animal and vegetable protein for their consumption and surplus sales for US36,000 over the year. 6,502 families, about 92% of the total families attended, are involved in savings for communitarian loans, this is an important financial resilience process, since is the only access they have for credit, currently the manage a fund of US88,900.00. 4,204 women involved in capacity building for sexual and reproductive health, self-esteem, project management and exchanges with other women. The work performed to promote integrated micro-watershed management resulted in the adoption of Milpa and Home Patio food systems and the introduction of 22 good practices to increase resilience to drought mostly related to water systems improvements, conservation and use of water resources, soil and forests. At this point, the practices are sustainable given that the families have been witnesses of the development (improvement) of their plots, which has implied more food availability, more yields and in some cases income generation through the surplus sales. The main challenges still the staff turn-over in the municipalities and the Ministry of Agriculture extensionists.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
